headline.print_headline: Putting a Crimp in the Hookah
headline.seo: Putting a Crimp in the Hookah
headline.main: Putting a Crimp in the Hookah

docs.lead_paragraph: Although water pipes are commonly viewed as less dangerous to health than cigarettes, they are just as bad, researchers say.
docs.snippet: Although water pipes are commonly viewed as less dangerous to health than cigarettes, they are just as bad, researchers say.

headline.main: Putting a Crimp in the Hookah

docs.abstract: Researchers say that smoking hookahs, or water pipes, commonly believed to be less harmful than cigarettes, carries equally hazardous health risks; authorities in many states are taking action against hookahs in what many say is newest front in ever-shifting war on tobacco; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Kevin Shapiro, a 20-year-old math and physics major at the University of Pennsylvania, first tried a hookah at a campus party. He liked the exotic water pipe so much that he chipped in to buy one for his fraternity house, where he says it makes a useful social lubricant at parties. Like many other students who are embracing hookahs on campuses nationwide, Mr. Shapiro believes that hookah smoke is less dangerous than cigarette smoke because it ''is filtered through water, so you get fewer solid particles.''
